cousers.Course Description: Introduction to the use of computers to solve problems arising in the physical, biological, and engineering sciences. Application of mathematical judgment, programming architecture, and flow control in solving scientific problems. Introduction to MATLAB or Python routines for numerical programming, computation, and visualization.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either MATH 125, Q SCI 292, or MATH 135
cousers.Key Words: Computation & Scientific Computing, Mathematical Biology, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Introduction to Neural Coding and Computation
cousers.Course Description: Introduces computational neuroscience, grounded in neuronal and synaptic biophysics. Works through mathematical description of how neurons encode information, and how neural activity is produced dynamically. Uses and teaches MATLAB and/or Python as a programming language to implement models of neuronal dynamics and to perform coding analysis.
cousers.Key Words: Bioengineering & Neural Engineering, Computation & Scientific Computing, Mathematical Biology

cousers.Course Name: Introduction to Differential Equations and Applications
cousers.Course Description: Introductory survey of ordinary differential equations; linear and nonlinear equations; Taylor series; and. Laplace transforms. Emphasizes on formulation, solution, and interpretation of results. Examples drawn from physical and biological sciences and engineering.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Mathematical Biology, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Applied Linear Algebra and Numerical Analysis
cousers.Course Description: Analysis and application of numerical methods and algorithms to problems in the applied sciences and engineering. Applied linear algebra, including eigenvalue problems. Emphasis on use of conceptual methods in engineering, mathematics, and science. Extensive use of MATLAB and/or Python for programming and solution techniques.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Numerical Analysis, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Covers traveling waves of linear equations, dispersion relation, stability, superposition and Fourier analysis, d'Alembert solution, standing waves, vibrations and separation of variables, traveling waves of nonlinear equations, conservation laws, characteristics, breaking, shocks, and rarefaction.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Numerical Analysis, Complex Analysis & Complex Variables

cousers.Course Description: Introductory survey of applied mathematics with emphasis on modeling of physical and biological problems in terms of differential equations. Formulation, solution, and interpretation of the results
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Modeling, Mathematical Biology, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Emphasizes acquisition of solution techniques; illustrates ideas with specific example problems arising in science and engineering. Includes applications of vector differential calculus, complex variables; line-surface integrals; integral theorems; and Taylor and Laurent series, and contour integration.
cousers.Key Words: Complex Analysis & Complex Variables, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Introduction to Dynamical Systems and Chaos
cousers.Course Description: Overview methods describing qualitative behavior of solutions on nonlinear differential equations. Phase space analysis of fixed pointed and periodic orbits. Bifurcation methods. Description of strange attractors and chaos. Introductions to maps. Applications: engineering, physics, chemistry, and biology.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Topology & Geometry, Numerical Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Covers separation of variables, Fourier series and Fourier transforms, Sturm-Liouville theory and special functions, eigenfunction expansions, and Greens functions.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: AMATH 401; and either AMATH 351, MATH 136, or MATH 207
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Complex Analysis & Complex Variables, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Examines fundamental models that arise in biology and their analysis through modern scientific computing. Covers discrete and continuous-time dynamics, in deterministic and stochastic settings, with application from molecular biology to neuroscience to population dynamics; statistical analysis of experimental data; and MATLAB and/or Python programming from scratch.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Biology, Mathematical Modeling, Computation & Scientific Computing

cousers.Course Name: Mathematical Analysis in Biology and Medicine
cousers.Course Description: Focuses on developing and analyzing mechanistic, dynamic models of biological systems and processes, to better understand their behavior and function. Applications drawn from many branches of biology and medicine. Provides experiences in applying differential equations, difference equations, and dynamical systems theory to biological problems.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Biology, Mathematical Modeling, Analysis & Real Analysis

cousers.Prerequisites: AMATH 301, AMATH 351, MATH 135, MATH 207, AMATH 352, MATH 136, MATH 208
cousers.Course Description: Survey of numerical techniques for differential equations. Emphasis is on implementation of numerical schemes for application problems. For ordinary differential equations, initial value problems and second order boundary value problems are covered. Methods for partial differential equations include finite differences, finite elements and spectral methods. Requires use of a scientific programming language (e.g., MATLAB or Python).
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: AMATH 301; either AMATH 351, MATH 135, or MATH 207; and either AMATH 352, MATH 136, or MATH 208
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems

cousers.Course Description: Exploratory and objective data analysis methods applied to the physical, engineering, and biological sciences. Brief review of statistical methods and their computational implementation for studying time series analysis, spectral analysis, filtering methods, principal component analysis, orthogonal mode decomposition, and image processing and compression.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: AMATH 301; and either AMATH 352, MATH 136, or MATH 208
cousers.Key Words: Data Science & Data Engineering, Analysis & Real Analysis, Computation & Scientific Computing

cousers.Course Description: Introduction to hardware, software, and programming for large-scale scientific computing. Overview of multicore, cluster, and supercomputer architectures; procedure and object oriented languages; parallel computing paradigms and languages; graphics and visualization of large data sets; validation and verification; and scientific software development.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: AMATH 481; and either AMATH 352, MATH 136 or MATH 208
cousers.Key Words: Computation & Scientific Computing, Data Science & Data Engineering, Computer Hardware & Architecture

cousers.Course Description: Emphasizes acquisition of solution techniques; illustrates ideas with specific example problems arising in science and engineering. Includes applications of vector differential calculus, complex variables; line-surface integrals; integral theorems; and Taylor and Laurent series, and contour integration.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in vector calculus or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Complex Analysis & Complex Variables, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Introduction to Dynamical Systems and Chaos
cousers.Course Description: Overview methods describing qualitative behavior of solutions on nonlinear differential equations. Phase space analysis of fixed pointed and periodic orbits. Bifurcation methods. Description of strange attractors and chaos. Introductions to maps. Applications: engineering, physics, chemistry, and biology.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in differential equations or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Topology & Geometry, Numerical Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Covers separation of variables, Fourier series and Fourier transforms, Sturm-Liouville theory and special functions, eigenfunction expansions, and Greens functions
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either AMATH 501 and a course in differential equations, or permission of instructor
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Complex Analysis & Complex Variables

cousers.Course Description: Eulerian equations for mass-motion; Navier-Stokes equation for viscous fluids, stress-strain relations; Kelvin's theorem, vortex dynamics; potential flows, flows with high-low Reynolds numbers; boundary layers, surface gravity waves; sound waves, and linear instability theory.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in partial differential equations or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Numerical Analysis, Complex Analysis & Complex Variables

cousers.Course Description: Necessary and sufficient conditions for a weak and strong extremum. Legendre transformation, Hamiltonian systems. Constraints and Lagrange multipliers. Space-time problems with examples from elasticity, electromagnetics, and fluid mechanics. Sturm-Liouville problems. Approximate methods.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: MATH 224; MATH 327; and either AMATH 351 or MATH 207
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Mathematical Modeling, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Mathematical foundations of combinatorial and network optimization with an emphasis on structure and algorithms with proofs. Topics include combinatorial and geometric methods for optimization of network flows, matching, traveling salesmen problem, cuts, and stable sets on graphs. Special emphasis on connections to linear and integer programming, duality theory, total unimodularity, and matroids.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either MATH 208 or AMATH 352; and any additional 400-level MATH course
cousers.Key Words: Optimization, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Maximization and minimization of functions of finitely many variables subject to constraints. Basic problem types and examples of applications; linear, convex, smooth, and nonsmooth programming. Optimality conditions. Saddlepoints and dual problems. Penalties, decomposition. Overview of computational approaches.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: Proficiency in linear algebra and advanced calculus/analysis; recommended: Strongly recommended: probability and statistics. Desirable: optimization, e.g. Math 408, and scientific programming experience in Matlab, Julia or Python.
cousers.Key Words: Optimization, Control Systems & Optimization, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Methods of solving optimization problems in finitely many variables, with or without constraints. Steepest descent, quasi-Newton methods. Quadratic programming and complementarity. Exact penalty methods, multiplier methods. Sequential quadratic programming. Cutting planes and nonsmooth optimization.
cousers.Key Words: Optimization, Control Systems & Optimization, Numerical Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Trajectories from ordinary differential equations with control variables. Controllability, optimality, maximum principle. Relaxation and existence of solutions. Techniques of nonsmooth analysis.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: real analysis on the level of MATH 426; background in optimization corresponding to MATH 515
cousers.Key Words: Control Systems & Optimization, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Optimization

cousers.Course Description: Examines fundamental models that arise in biology and their analysis through modern scientific computing. Covers discrete and continuous-time dynamics, in deterministic and stochastic settings, with application from molecular biology to neuroscience to population dynamics; statistical analysis of experimental data; and MATLAB and/or Python programming from scratch.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in differential equations or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Biology, Mathematical Modeling, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Examines fundamental models that arise in biology and their analysis through modern scientific computing. Covers discrete and continuous-time dynamics, in deterministic and stochastic settings, with application from molecular biology to neuroscience to population dynamics; statistical analysis of experimental data; and MATLAB and/or Python programming from scratch.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in differential equations or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Biology, Mathematical Modeling, Computation & Scientific Computing

cousers.Course Name: Mathematical Analysis in Biology and Medicine
cousers.Course Description: Focuses on developing and analyzing mechanistic, dynamic models of biological systems and processes, to better understand their behavior and function. Applications drawn from many branches of biology and medicine. Provides experiences in applying differential equations, difference equations, and dynamical systems theory to biological problems.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either courses in differential equations and statistics and probability, or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Biology, Mathematical Modeling, Analysis & Real Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Examines partial differential equations for biological dynamics in space and time. Draws examples from molecular and cell biology, ecology, epidemiology, and neurobiology. Topics include reaction-diffusion equations for biochemical reactions, calcium wave propagation in excitable medium, and models for invading biological populations.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in partial differential equations or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Biology, Mathematical Modeling, Bioengineering & Neural Engineering

cousers.Course Description: Develops a coherent mathematical theory for processes inside living cells. Focuses on analyzing dynamics leading to functions of cellular components (gene regulation, signaling biochemistry, metabolic networks, cytoskeletal biomechanics, and epigenetic inheritance) using deterministic and stochastic models.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either courses in dynamical systems, partial differential equations, and probability, or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Biology, Mathematical Modeling, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Mathematics of Genome Analysis and Molecular Modeling
cousers.Course Description: Covers genome analysis, including bioinformatics and molecular modeling in terms of molecular dynamics.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either AMATH 506 or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Biology, Mathematical Modeling, Bioengineering & Neural Engineering

cousers.Course Name: Neural Control of Movement: A Computational Perspective
cousers.Course Description: Systematic overview of sensorimotor function on multiple levels of analysis, with emphasis on the phenomenology amenable to computational modeling. Topics include musculoskeletal mechanics, neural networks, optimal control and Bayesian inference, learning and adaptation, internal models, and neural coding and decoding.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: vector calculus, linear algebra, MATLAB, Python, or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Control Systems & Optimization, Robotics & Automation, Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning

cousers.Course Description: Covers mathematical analysis and simulation of neural systems - singles cells, networks, and populations - via tolls of dynamical systems, stochastic processes, and signal processing. Topics include single-neuron excitability and oscillations; network structure and synchrony; and stochastic and statistical dynamics of large cell populations.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either familiarity with dynamical systems and probability, or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Modeling, Mathematical Biology, Probability & Stochastic Processes

cousers.Course Description: Considers models, methods, and issues in population ecology. Topics include the effects of density dependence, delays, demographic stochasticity, and age structure on population growth; population interactions (predation, competition, and mutualism); and application of optimal control theory to the management of renewable resources.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in differential equations or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Modeling, Mathematical Biology, Probability & Stochastic Processes

cousers.Course Description: Introduces stochastic and deterministic methods for mathematical modeling of cancer evolution. Particular emphasis on branching process models of cancer initiation, progression and response to therapy, and their relationship to clinical, epidemiological and sequencing data. The course introduces both analytic and computational approaches for modeling cancer, and gets students acquainted with the current research in the field.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: Previous experience with calculus, probability, ODEs and programming or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Modeling, Mathematical Biology, Probability & Stochastic Processes

cousers.Course Name: Introduction to Probability and Random Processes
cousers.Course Description: Introduces concepts in probability and stochastic dynamics needed for mathematical modeling. In addition to the basics of probability, includes martingales, Markov chains, and Chapman-Kolmogorov equations. Introduces concepts in measure theory from an applied mathematics perspective. Emphasis on presenting theories with examples and a variety of computational methods.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either undergraduate coursework in partial differential equations; and undergraduate coursework in probability and statistics, or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Probability & Stochastic Processes, Mathematical Modeling, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Stochastic dynamical systems aimed at students in applied math. Introduces basic concepts in continuous stochastic processes including Brownian motion, stochastic differential equations, Levy processes, Kolmogorov forward and backward equations, and Hamilton-Jacobi-Bellman partial differential equations. Presents theories with applications from physics, biology, and finance.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: AMATH 561 or permission of instructor; recommended: undergraduate course in probability and statistics.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Probability & Stochastic Processes, Mathematical Biology

cousers.Course Description: Introduces fundamental concepts of network science and graph theory for complex dynamical systems. Merges concepts from model selection, information theory, statistical inference, neural networks, deep learning, and machine learning for building reduced order models of dynamical systems using sparse sampling of high-dimensional data.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: AMATH 561 and AMATH 562, or instructor permission
cousers.Key Words: Complex Analysis & Complex Variables, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Mathematical Biology

cousers.Course Description: Complex variable and associated topics. Branch cuts, series and product expansions. Contour integration, numerical implications. Harmonic functions. Complex potential (and singularities) in physical problems. Conformal mapping; applications and examples. Fourier and Laplace transforms and applications.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either AMATH 401or equivalent, or permission of instructor
cousers.Key Words: Complex Analysis & Complex Variables, Analysis & Real Analysis, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Advanced Methods for Ordinary Differential Equations
cousers.Course Description: Regular and singular points of differential equations. Asymptotic expansions for solutions of linear ordinary equations. Regular and singular perturbations. Asymptotic evaluation of integrals. Boundary layers and the WKB method. The method of multiple scales.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in differential equations or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Numerical Analysis, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Advanced Methods for Partial Differential Equations
cousers.Course Description: Analytical solution techniques for linear partial differential equations. Discussion of how these arise in science and engineering. Transform and Green's function methods. Classification of second-order equations, characteristics. Conservation laws, shocks.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in partial differential equations or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Numerical Analysis, Complex Analysis & Complex Variables

cousers.Course Description: Introduction to interpolation and approximation of data and functions by polynomials, piecewise polynomials, and trigonometric series. Covers aspects of implementation including FFTs and the chebfun software. Spectral methods for solving differential equations serve as main motivating application, along with other approximation problems.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: AMATH 584; MATH 585; AMATH 586; programing experience in either Matlab or Python; or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Computer-Aided Mathematics, Optimization, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Name: Intelligent Control through Learning and Optimization
cousers.Course Description: Design or near-optimal controllers for complex dynamical systems, using analytical techniques, machine learning, and optimization. Topics from deterministic and stochastic optimal control, reinforcement learning and dynamic programming, numerical optimization in the context of control, and robotics.
cousers.Key Words: Control Systems & Optimization, Artificial Intelligence & Machine Learning, Optimization

cousers.Course Name: Coherent Structures, Pattern Formation and Solitons
cousers.Course Description: Methods for nonlinear partial differential equations (PDEs) leading to coherent structures and patterns. Includes symmetries, conservations laws, stability Hamiltonian and variation methods of PDEs; interactions of structures such as waves or solitons; Lax pairs and inverse scattering; and Painleve analysis.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in partial differential equations or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Topology & Geometry

cousers.Course Name: Conservation Laws and Finite Volume Methods
cousers.Course Description: Theory of linear and nonlinear hyperbolic conservation laws modeling wave propagation in gases, fluids, and solids. Shock and rarefaction waves. Finite volume methods for numerical approximation of solutions; Godunov's method and high-resolution TVD methods. Stability, convergence, and entropy conditions.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either AMATH 586 or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Numerical Analysis, Mathematical Modeling

cousers.Course Description: Overview of ways in which complex dynamics arise in nonlinear dynamical systems. Topics include bifurcation theory, universality, Poincare maps, routes to chaos, horseshoe maps, Hamiltonian chaos, fractal dimensions, Liapunov exponents, and the analysis of time series. Examples from biology, mechanics, and other fields.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either AMATH 502 or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Complex Analysis & Complex Variables, Topology & Geometry

cousers.Course Description: Survey of numerical techniques for differential equations. Emphasis is on implementation of numerical schemes for application problems. For ordinary differential equations, initial value problems and second order boundary value problems are covered. Methods for partial differential equations include finite differences, finite elements and spectral methods. Requires use of a scientific programming language (e.g., MATLAB or Python).
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in numerical analysis or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems

cousers.Course Description: Exploratory and objective data analysis methods applied to the physical, engineering, and biological sciences. Brief review of statistical methods and their computational implementation for studying time series analysis, spectral analysis, filtering methods, principal component analysis, orthogonal mode decomposition, and image processing and compression.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either familiarity with a scientific programming language and college-level coursework in linear algebra, or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Data Science & Data Engineering, Analysis & Real Analysis, Computation & Scientific Computing

cousers.Course Description: Introduction to hardware, software, and programming for large-scale scientific computing. Overview of multicore, cluster, and supercomputer architectures; procedure and object oriented languages; parallel computing paradigms and languages; graphics and visualization of large data sets; validation and verification; and scientific software development.
cousers.Key Words: Computation & Scientific Computing, Data Science & Data Engineering, Computer Hardware & Architecture

cousers.Course Description: Singular value decomposition. QR factorization and linear least squares problems. Conditioning of problems and stability of algorithms. LU (lower-upper) factorization. Eigenvalue problems. Iterative methods for solving linear systems of equations.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in linear algebra or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Complex Analysis & Complex Variables

cousers.Prerequisites: AMATH 352, AMATH 481, AMATH 581, AMATH 584, MATH 584, AMATH 584, MATH 584
cousers.Course Description: Iterative methods for solving nonlinear systems of equations. Numerical approximation and interpolation. Fast Fourier transform. Operator spectrum approximation. Numerical differentiation and integration. Numerical methods for ordinary differential equations.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either AMATH 352 (or equivalent), AMATH 481 (or equivalent), AMATH 581, AMATH 584/MATH 584, or permission of instructor; recommended: AMATH 584/MATH 584.
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Optimization

cousers.Course Name: Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
cousers.Prerequisites: AMATH 352, AMATH 481, AMATH 569, AMATH 581, AMATH 584, MATH 584, AMATH 585, MATH 585, AMATH 584, MATH 584, AMATH 585, MATH 585
cousers.Course Description: Method of lines discretization. Initial and boundary value problems, including finite difference methods and spectral methods. Elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic and dispersive equations. Stability, accuracy, and convergence theory.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either AMATH 352 (or equivalent), AMATH 481 (or equivalent), AMATH 569 (which may be taken concurrently), AMATH 581, AMATH 584/MATH 584, AMATH 585/MATH 585, or permission of instructor; recommended: AMATH 584/MATH 584 and AMATH 585/MATH 585.
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Similar to the first three terms of high school algebra. Assumes no previous experience in algebra. Open only to students [1] in the Educational Opportunity Program or [2] admitted with an entrance deficiency in mathematics.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Mathematics Education & Career Development

cousers.Course Description: Similar to the first three terms of high school algebra.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Topology & Geometry, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Continues the study of algebra begun in MATH 100 and MATH 102 with emphasis on functions (polynomial, rational, logarithmic, exponential, and trigonometric).
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Course awarded based on International Baccalaureate (IB) score. Consult the Admissions Exams for Credit website for more information.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematics Education & Career Development, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematical Biology

cousers.Course Description: Course awarded based on International Baccalaureate (IB) score. Consult the Admissions Exams for Credit website for more information.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematics Education & Career Development, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Data Science & Data Engineering

cousers.Course Description: Use of graphs and algebraic functions as found in business and economics. Algebraic and graphical manipulations to solve problems. Exponential and logarithm functions; various applications to growth of money. Recommended: completion of Department of Mathematics' Guided Self-Placement.
cousers.Key Words: Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Application of Calculus to Business and Economics
cousers.Course Description: Rates of change, tangent, derivative, accumulation, area, integrals in specific contexts, particularly economics. Techniques of differentiation and integration. Application to problem solving. Optimization. Credit does not apply toward a mathematics major. Course equivalent to: B MATH 144 and TMATH 122. Course overlaps with: MATH 124; Q SCI 291; STMATH 113; STMATH 114; STMATH 124; and TMATH 124.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 111 or MATH 120, or a minimum score of 2 on the AP MATH AB exam.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematics Education & Career Development, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematical Biology

cousers.Course Name: Introduction to Taylor Polynomials and Taylor Series
cousers.Course Description: Brief introduction to Taylor polynomials, error bounds, and Taylor series.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 125, or a minimum score of 4 on BC advanced placement test. Credit/no-credit only.
cousers.Key Words: Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Numerical Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Basic properties of functions, graphs; with emphasis on linear, quadratic, trigonometric, exponential functions and their inverses. Emphasis on multi-step problem solving. Maximum 10 credits allowed between TMATH 115; TMATH 116; TMATH 120; and MATH 120. Course equivalent to: TMATH 120. Course overlaps with: B MATH 123. Recommended: completion of Department of Mathematics' Guided Self-Placement.
cousers.Key Words: Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: First quarter in calculus of functions of a single variable. Emphasizes differential calculus. Emphasizes applications and problem solving using the tools of calculus. Course equivalent to: STMATH 124 and TMATH 124. Course overlaps with: MATH 112; B MATH 144; STMATH 113; STMATH 114; and TMATH 122. Recommended: completion of Department of Mathematics' Guided Self-Placement.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematics Education & Career Development

cousers.Course Description: Second quarter in the calculus of functions of a single variable. Emphasizes integral calculus. Emphasizes applications and problem solving using the tools of calculus. Cannot be taken for credit if credit has already been earned for MATH 207. Course equivalent to: STMATH 125 and TMATH 125.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 124, score of 3 on AB advanced placement test, or score of 3 on BC advanced placement test.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematics Education & Career Development

cousers.Course Description: Third quarter in calculus sequence. Introduction to Taylor polynomials and Taylor series, vector geometry in three dimensions, introduction to multivariable differential calculus, double integrals in Cartesian and polar coordinates. Course equivalent to: STMATH 126 and TMATH 126. Course overlaps with: MATH 136.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 125, a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 134, or a minimum score of 4 on BC advanced placement test.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Algebra & Abstract Algebra

cousers.Course Description: Covers the material of MATH 124, MATH 125, MATH 126; MATH 207, MATH 208. First year of a two-year accelerated sequence. May receive advanced placement (AP) credit for MATH 124 after taking MATH 134. For students with above average preparation, interest, and ability in mathematics.
cousers.Key Words: Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematics Education & Career Development, Algebra & Abstract Algebra

cousers.Course Description: Covers the material of MATH 124, MATH 125, MATH 126; MATH 207, MATH 208. First year of a two-year accelerated sequence. May receive advanced placement (AP) credit for MATH 125 after taking MATH 135. For students with above average preparation, interest, and ability in mathematics.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 134.
cousers.Key Words: Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematics Education & Career Development, Algebra & Abstract Algebra

cousers.Course Description: Covers the material of MATH 124, MATH 125, MATH 126; MATH 207, MATH 208. First year of a two-year accelerated sequence. For students with above average preparation, interest, and ability in mathematics. Course overlaps with: MATH 126.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 135.
cousers.Key Words: Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematics Education & Career Development, Algebra & Abstract Algebra

cousers.Course Description: Introductory course in ordinary differential equations. Includes first- and second-order equations and Laplace transform. Course overlaps with: STMATH 207 and TMATH 207.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Numerical Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Systems of linear equations, vector spaces, matrices, subspaces, orthogonality, least squares, eigenvalues, eigenvectors, applications. For students in engineering, mathematics, and the sciences. Course overlaps with: STMATH 208 and TMATH 208.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Topology & Geometry, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: First order systems of linear differential equations, Fourier series and partial differential equations, and the phase plane.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a minimum grade of 2.0 in both MATH 207 and MATH 208, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 136.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Numerical Analysis, Mathematical Modeling

cousers.Course Description: Topics include double and triple integrals, the chain rule, vector fields, line and surface integrals. Culminates in the theorems of Green and Stokes, along with the Divergence Theorem.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 126 or MATH 136.
cousers.Key Words: Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Topology & Geometry, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Name: Exploring Opportunities in the Mathematical Sciences
cousers.Course Description: Topics include finding a community; diversity and equity issues in STEM and the mathematical sciences; academic planning; navigating academic support services; undergraduate research; graduate school; careers in the mathematical sciences. For students interested in careers in the mathematical sciences. Credit does not apply toward a mathematics major or an applied and computational mathematical sciences major at UW Seattle. Credit/no-credit only.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematics Education & Career Development, Mathematical Biology, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Mathematical arguments and the writing of proofs in an elementary setting. Elementary set theory, elementary examples of functions and operations on functions, the principle of induction, counting, elementary number theory, elementary combinatorics, recurrence relations.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 126 or MATH 136.
cousers.Key Words: Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Brief introduction to some of the fundamental ideas of elementary number theory.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 126 and MATH 300, or minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 136, or minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 334.
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Advanced Linear Algebra Tools and Applications
cousers.Course Description: Eigenvalues, eigenvectors, and diagonalization of matrices: nonnegative, symmetric, and positive semidefinite matrices. Orthogonality, singular value decomposition, complex matrices, infinite dimensional vector spaces, and vector spaces over finite fields. Applications to spectral graph theory, rankings, error correcting codes, linear regression, Fourier transforms, principal component analysis, and solving univariate polynomial equations.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.7 in either MATH 208 or MATH 308, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 136.
cousers.Key Words: Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Topology & Geometry

cousers.Course Description: Covers number systems, fields, order, the least upper bound property, sequences, limits, liminf and limsup, series, convergence tests, alternating series, absolute convergence, re-arrangements of series, continuous functions of a real variable, and uniform continuity. Course overlaps with: STMATH 424 and TMATH 424.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 300 or MATH 334.
cousers.Key Words: Analysis & Real Analysis, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Numerical Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Introduction to proofs and rigor; uniform convergence, Fourier series and partial differential equations, vector calculus, complex variables. Students who complete this sequence are not required to take MATH 209, MATH 224, MATH 300, MATH 327, MATH 328, and MATH 427. Second year of an accelerated two-year sequence; prepares students for senior-level mathematics courses.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 136, or a minimum grade of 3.0 in MATH 126 and a minimum grade of 3.0 in either MATH 207 or MATH 307 and a minimum grade of 3.0 in either MATH 208 or MATH 308.
cousers.Key Words: Computer-Aided Mathematics, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Mathematics Education & Career Development

cousers.Course Description: Introduction to proofs and rigor; uniform convergence, Fourier series and partial differential equations, vector calculus, complex variables. Students who complete this sequence are not required to take MATH 209, MATH 224, MATH 300, MATH 327, MATH 328, and MATH 427. Second year of an accelerated two-year sequence; prepares students for senior-level mathematics courses.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 334.
cousers.Key Words: Computer-Aided Mathematics, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Mathematics Education & Career Development

cousers.Course Description: Introduction to proofs and rigor; uniform convergence, Fourier series and partial differential equations, vector calculus, complex variables. Students who complete this sequence are not required to take MATH 209, MATH 224, MATH 300, MATH 327, MATH 328, and MATH 427. Second year of an accelerated two-year sequence; prepares students for senior-level mathematics courses.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 335.
cousers.Key Words: Computer-Aided Mathematics, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Mathematics Education & Career Development

cousers.Course Description: Linear algebra from a theoretical point of view. Abstract vector spaces and linear transformations, bases and linear independence, matrix representations, Jordan canonical form, linear functionals, dual space, bilinear forms and inner product spaces. Course overlaps with: STMATH 409.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 334, or both MATH 208 and MATH 300.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Topology & Geometry, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems

cousers.Course Description: Explores the artful side of problem-solving, with examples from various fields across mathematics, including combinatorics, number theory, algebra, geometry, probability, and analysis.
cousers.Key Words: Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematical Biology, Mathematics Education & Career Development

cousers.Prerequisites: CSE 121, CSE 122, CSE 123, CSE 142, CSE 143, AMATH 301, MATH 136, MATH 208
cousers.Course Description: Introduction to methods of discrete mathematics, including topics from graph theory, network flows, and combinatorics. Emphasis on these tools to formulate models and solve problems arising in variety of applications, such as computer science, biology, and management science.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in either CSE 121, CSE 122, CSE 123, CSE 142, CSE 143, or AMATH 301; and a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 136 or MATH 208.
cousers.Key Words: Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Mathematical Modeling, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Preparation for careers in the mathematical sciences. Focuses on identification of key skills; creating an effective resume; articulating interests and experiences; doing informational interviews; and demonstrating professional communication. Credit does not apply toward a mathematics major or an applied and computational mathematical sciences major at UW Seattle. Credit/no-credit only.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematics Education & Career Development, Mathematical Biology, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Axiomatic definitions of probability; random variables; conditional probability and Bayes' theorem; expectations and variance; named distributions: binomial, geometric, Poisson, uniform (discrete and continuous), normal and exponential; normal and Poisson approximations to binomial. Transformations of a single random variable. Markov and Chebyshev's inequality. Weak law of large numbers for finite variance. Course overlaps with: E E 391; STMATH 392; and TMATH 393.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 126, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 136. Offered: jointly with STAT 394;
cousers.Key Words: Probability & Stochastic Processes, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Jointly distributed random variables; conditional distributions and densities; conditional expectations and variance; covariance, correlation, and Cauchy-Schwarz inequality; bivariate normal distribution; multivariate transformations; moment generating functions; sums of independent random variables; Central Limit Theorem; Chernoff's inequality; Jensen's inequality.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 394/STAT 394, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in STAT 340.
cousers.Key Words: Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Probability & Stochastic Processes, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems

cousers.Course Name: Finite Markov Chains and Monte-Carlo Methods
cousers.Course Description: Finite Markov chains; stationary distributions; time reversals; classification of states; classical Markov chains; convergence in total variation distance and L2; spectral analysis; relaxation time; Monte Carlo techniques: rejection sampling, Metropolis-Hastings, Gibbs sampler, Glauber dynamics, hill climb and simulated annealing; harmonic functions and martingales for Markov chains.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 208; and either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 394/STAT 394 and STAT 395/MATH 395, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in STAT 340 and STAT 341, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in STAT 340 and STAT 395/MATH 395. Offered: jointly with STAT 396;
cousers.Key Words: Probability & Stochastic Processes, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Control Systems & Optimization

cousers.Course Description: Elementary theory of rings and fields: basic number theory of the integers, congruence of integers and modular arithmetic, basic examples of commutative and non-commutative rings, an in depth discussion of polynomial rings, irreducibility of polynomials, polynomial congruence rings, ideals, quotient rings, isomorphism theorems. Additional topics including Euclidean rings, principal ideal domains and unique factorization domains may be covered. Course overlaps with: MATH 411; MATH 412; and STMATH 403.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 300 and a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 208 or MATH 308, a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 334, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 136 and a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 300.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Topology & Geometry

cousers.Course Description: Elementary theory of groups: basic examples of finite and infinite groups, symmetric and alternating groups, dihedral groups, subgroups, normal subgroups, quotient groups, isomorphism theorems, finite abelian groups. Additional topics including Sylow theorems, group actions, congugacy classes and counting techniques may be covered. Course overlaps with: MATH 411; MATH 412; and STMATH 402.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 402.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Topics in algebra chosen from Galois theory, theory of modules, geometric group actions, and the theory of rings and fields. Specific content determined by instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Topology & Geometry, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Maximization and minimization of linear functions subject to constraints consisting of linear equations and inequalities; linear programming and mathematical modeling. Simplex method, elementary games and duality.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 136, MATH 208, MATH 308, or AMATH 352.
cousers.Key Words: Optimization, Mathematical Modeling, Control Systems & Optimization

cousers.Course Description: Maximization and minimization of nonlinear functions, constrained and unconstrained; nonlinear programming problems and methods. Lagrange multipliers; Kuhn-Tucker conditions, convexity. Quadratic programming.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 407 or MATH 464; minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 327 or MATH 334.
cousers.Key Words: Optimization, Control Systems & Optimization, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems

cousers.Course Description: Maximization and minimization problems in graphs and networks (shortest paths, minimum spanning trees, maximum flows, minimum cost flows); transportation and trans-shipment problems, NP-completeness.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 407; and either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 300, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 334.
cousers.Key Words: Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Optimization, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Name: Introduction to Modern Algebra with Applications I
cousers.Course Description: Basic concepts of abstract algebra with an emphasis on problem solving, constructing proofs, and communication of mathematical ideas. Course overlaps with: MATH 402 and MATH 403.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 136 or MATH 208.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Name: Introduction to Modern Algebra with Applications II
cousers.Course Description: Basic concepts of abstract algebra with an emphasis on problem solving, constructing proofs, and communication of mathematical ideas. Course overlaps with: MATH 402 and MATH 403.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 411.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Survey of the development of mathematics from its earliest beginnings through the first half of the twentieth century. Course overlaps with: STMATH 420.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 126 or MATH 136.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematics Education & Career Development, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematical Biology

cousers.Course Description: Focuses on functions of a real variable, including limits of functions, differentiation, Rolle's theorem, mean value theorems, Taylor's theorem, and the intermediate value theorem for derivatives. Riemann-Stieltjes integrals, change of variable, Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, and integration by parts. Sequences and series of functions, uniform convergence, and power series. Course overlaps with: STMATH 424 and STMATH 425.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 327, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 335.
cousers.Key Words: Complex Analysis & Complex Variables, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Introduction to metric spaces and multivariable differential calculus: Euclidean spaces, abstract metric spaces, compactness, Bolzano-Weierstrass property, sequences and their limits, Cauchy sequences and completeness, Heine-Borel Theorem, continuity, uniform continuity, connected sets and the intermediate value theorem. Derivatives of functions of several variables, chain rule, mean value theorem, inverse and implicit function theorems. Course overlaps with: STMATH 425.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 136 or MATH 208; and a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 335 or MATH 424.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Lebesgue measure on the reals. Construction of the Lebesgue integral and its basic properties. Monotone Convergence Theorem, Fatou's Lemma, and Dominated Convergence Theorem. Integration of series. Continuity and differentiability theorems for functions defined by integrals. Introduction to general measures and integration.
cousers.Key Words: Analysis & Real Analysis, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Complex numbers; analytic functions; sequences and series; complex integration; Cauchy integral formula; Taylor and Laurent series; uniform convergence; residue theory; conformal mapping. Topics chosen from: Fourier series and integrals, Laplace transforms, infinite products, complex dynamics; additional topics chose by instructor. Course overlaps with: STMATH 427 and TMATH 427.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 327 or MATH 335.
cousers.Key Words: Complex Analysis & Complex Variables, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Numerical Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Continuation of MATH 427.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 427 or MATH 336
cousers.Key Words: Complex Analysis & Complex Variables, Numerical Analysis, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Metric and topological spaces, convergence, continuity, finite products, connectedness, and compactness. Course overlaps with: STMATH 441.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 327 or MATH 335.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Examines curves in the plane and 3-spaces, surfaces in 3-space, tangent planes, first and second fundamental forms, curvature, the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem, and possible other selected topics.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 334, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 208 and a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 224; and minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 441.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems

cousers.Course Description: Further examines curves in the plane and 3-spaces, surfaces in 3-space, tangent planes, first and second fundamental forms, curvature, the Gauss-Bonnet Theorem, and possible other selected topics.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems

cousers.Course Description: Concepts of geometry from multiple approaches; discovery, formal and informal reasoning, transformations, coordinates, exploration using computers and models. Topics selected from Euclidean plane and space geometry, spherical geometry, non-Euclidean geometries, fractal geometry. Course overlaps with: STMATH 444.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 334, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 208 and MATH 300.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Mathematical Biology

cousers.Course Description: Concepts of geometry from multiple approaches; discovery, formal and informal reasoning, transformations, coordinates, exploration using computers and models. Topics selected from Euclidean plane and space geometry, spherical geometry, non-Euclidean geometries, fractal geometry.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 444.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Mathematical Biology, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Basic counting techniques and combinatorial objects. Topics may include permutations, sets, multisets, compositions, partitions, graphs, generating functions, the inclusion-exclusion principle, bijective proofs, and recursions.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 334, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 300 and a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 136 or MATH 208.
cousers.Key Words: Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Structural theorems and methods in combinatorics, including those from extremal combinatorics and probabilistic combinatorics. Topics may include graphs, trees, posets, strategic games, polytopes, Ramsey theory, and matroids.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 461 or CSE 421.
cousers.Key Words: Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory, Topology & Geometry

cousers.Course Description: Basic principles of numerical analysis, classical interpolation and approximation formulas, finite differences and difference equations. Numerical methods in algebra, systems of linear equations, matrix inversion, successive approximations, iterative and relaxation methods. Numerical differentiation and integration. Solution of differential equations and systems of such equations.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 136, MATH 208, or MATH 335.
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Mathematical Modeling

cousers.Course Description: Basic principles of numerical analysis, classical interpolation and approximation formulas, finite differences and difference equations. Numerical methods in algebra, systems of linear equations, matrix inversion, successive approximations, iterative and relaxation methods. Numerical differentiation and integration. Solution of differential equations and systems of such equations.
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Random walks, Markov chains, branching processes, Poisson process, point processes, birth and death processes, queuing theory, stationary processes.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in either MATH 394/STAT 394 or STAT 340; and a minimum grade of 2.0 in either STAT 395/MATH 395 or MATH 396/STAT 396. Offered: jointly with STAT 491;
cousers.Key Words: Probability & Stochastic Processes, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Mathematical Modeling

cousers.Course Description: Introduces elementary continuous-time discrete/continuous-state stochastic processes and their applications. Covers useful classes of continuous-time stochastic processes (e.g., Poisson process, renewal processes, birth and birth-and-death processes, Brownian motion, diffusion processes, and geometric Brownian motion) and shows how useful they are for solving problems of practical interest.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 2.0 in MATH 491/STAT 491.
cousers.Key Words: Probability & Stochastic Processes, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Introductory stochastic calculus mathematical foundation for pricing options and derivatives. Basic stochastic analysis tools, including stochastic integrals, stochastic differential equations, Ito's formula, theorems of Girsanov and Feynman-Kac, Black-Scholes option pricing, American and exotic options, bond options. Course overlaps with: CFRM 450.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: minimum grade of 2.0 in either STAT 395/MATH 395, or a minimum grade of 2.0 in STAT 340 and STAT 341.
cousers.Key Words: Probability & Stochastic Processes, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: First quarter of a three-quarter sequence covering group theory; field theory and Galois theory; commutative rings and modules, linear algebra, theory of forms; representation theory, associative rings and modules; commutative algebra and elementary algebraic geometry.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Topology & Geometry

cousers.Course Description: Continuation of MATH 504.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Continuation of MATH 505.
cousers.Key Words: Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Topology & Geometry, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: First quarter of a three-quarter sequence covering homological algebra, advanced commutative algebra, and Lie algebras and representation theory. Specific topics include chain complexes, resolutions and derived functors, dimension theory, Cohen-Macaulay modules, Gorenstein rings, local cohomology, local duality, triangulated and derived categories, group cohomology, and structure and representation.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Second quarter of a three-quarter sequence covering homological algebra, advanced commutative algebra, and Lie algebras and representation theory. Specific topics include chain complexes, resolutions and derived functors, dimension theory, Cohen-Macaulay modules, Gorenstein rings, local cohomology, local duality, triangulated and derived categories, group cohomology, and structure and representation.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Third quarter of a three-quarter sequence covering homological algebra, advanced commutative algebra, and Lie algebras and representation theory. Specific topics include chain complexes, resolutions and derived functors, dimension theory, Cohen-Macaulay modules, Gorenstein rings, local cohomology, local duality, triangulated and derived categories, group cohomology, and structure and representation.
cousers.Key Words: Topology & Geometry, Algebra & Abstract Algebra, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Mathematical foundations of combinatorial and network optimization with an emphasis on structure and algorithms with proofs. Topics include combinatorial and geometric methods for optimization of network flows, matching, traveling salesmen problem, cuts, and stable sets on graphs. Special emphasis on connections to linear and integer programming, duality theory, total unimodularity, and matroids.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either MATH 208 or AMATH 352; and any additional 400-level MATH course.
cousers.Key Words: Optimization, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Maximization and minimization of functions of finitely many variables subject to constraints. Basic problem types and examples of applications; linear, convex, smooth, and nonsmooth programming. Optimality conditions. Saddlepoints and dual problems. Penalties, decomposition. Overview of computational approaches.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: Proficiency in linear algebra and advanced calculus/analysis; recommended: Strongly recommended: probability and statistics. Desirable: optimization, e.g. Math 408, and scientific programming experience in Matlab, Julia or Python.
cousers.Key Words: Optimization, Control Systems & Optimization, Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Methods of solving optimization problems in finitely many variables, with or without constraints. Steepest descent, quasi-Newton methods. Quadratic programming and complementarity. Exact penalty methods, multiplier methods. Sequential quadratic programming. Cutting planes and nonsmooth optimization.
cousers.Key Words: Optimization, Control Systems & Optimization, Numerical Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Trajectories from ordinary differential equations with control variables. Controllability, optimality, maximum principle. Relaxation and existence of solutions. Techniques of nonsmooth analysis.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: real analysis on the level of MATH 426; background in optimization corresponding to MATH 515.
cousers.Key Words: Control Systems & Optimization, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Optimization

cousers.Course Description: Measure theory and integration, independence, laws of large numbers. Fourier analysis of distributions, central limit problem and infinitely divisible laws, conditional expectations, martingales.
cousers.Key Words: Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Probability & Stochastic Processes, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Measure theory and integration, independence, laws of large numbers. Fourier analysis of distributions, central limit problem and infinitely divisible laws, conditional expectations, martingales.

cousers.Course Description: Measure theory and integration, independence, laws of large numbers. Fourier analysis of distributions, central limit problem and infinitely divisible laws, conditional expectations, martingales.
cousers.Key Words: Combinatorics & Discrete Mathematics, Probability & Stochastic Processes, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

Working knowledge of real variables, general topology, complex variables.

cousers.Key Words: Mathematical Biology, Topology & Geometry, Analysis & Real Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Singular value decomposition. QR factorization and linear least squares problems. Conditioning of problems and stability of algorithms. LU (lower-upper) factorization. Eigenvalue problems. Iterative methods for solving linear systems of equations.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either a course in linear algebra or permission of instructor.
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Complex Analysis & Complex Variables

cousers.Prerequisites: AMATH 352, AMATH 481, AMATH 581, AMATH 584, MATH 584, AMATH 584, MATH 584
cousers.Course Description: Iterative methods for solving nonlinear systems of equations. Numerical approximation and interpolation. Fast Fourier transform. Operator spectrum approximation. Numerical differentiation and integration. Numerical methods for ordinary differential equations.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either AMATH 352 (or equivalent), AMATH 481 (or equivalent), AMATH 581, AMATH 584/MATH 584, or permission of instructor; recommended: AMATH 584/MATH 584.
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Optimization

cousers.Course Name: Numerical Methods for Partial Differential Equations
cousers.Prerequisites: AMATH 352, AMATH 481, AMATH 569, AMATH 581, AMATH 584, MATH 584, AMATH 585, MATH 585
cousers.Course Description: Method of lines discretization. Initial and boundary value problems, including finite difference methods and spectral methods. Elliptic, parabolic, hyperbolic and dispersive equations. Stability, accuracy, and convergence theory.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either AMATH 352 (or equivalent), AMATH 481 (or equivalent), AMATH 569 (which may be taken concurrently), AMATH 581, AMATH 584/MATH 584, AMATH 585/MATH 585, or permission of instructor;
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Course Description: Lab-based course focused on a wide range of basic hands-on skills for electrical and computer engineers. Provides an overview of topic areas and career paths in electrical and computer engineering. Topics include introduction to physical circuit building, microcontroller programming, proportional-integral-derivative design, soldering, circuit simulation, 3D design and printing, printed circuit board control, and sensors.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: CSE 122, CSE 123, CSE 142, or CSE 143, any of which may be taken concurrently
cousers.Key Words: Computer Hardware & Architecture, Mathematics Education & Career Development, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Introduces analog circuits interfacing sensors to digital systems. /includes connection, attenuation, amplification, sampling, filtering, termination, controls, Kirchhoff's Laws, sources, resistors, op amps, capacitors, inductors, PSice, and MATLAB. Intended for non-EE majors.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: MATH 126 or MATH 136; and either PHYS 122 or PHYS 142
cousers.Key Words: Signal Processing & Communication, Bioengineering & Neural Engineering, Embedded & Real-Time Systems

cousers.Course Description: Introduces analog circuits interfacing sensors to digital systems. /includes connection, attenuation, amplification, sampling, filtering, termination, controls, Kirchhoff's Laws, sources, resistors, op amps, capacitors, inductors, PSice, and MATLAB. Intended for non-EE majors
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either MATH 136, or MATH 126 and either MATH 207, MATH 307, or AMATH 351, any of which may be taken concurrently; and either PHYS 122 or PHYS 142.
cousers.Key Words: Power Systems & Energy Engineering, Computer Hardware & Architecture, Bioengineering & Neural Engineering

cousers.Course Description: Electric circuit theory. Analysis of circuits with sinusoidal signals. Phasors, system functions, and complex frequency. Frequency response. Computer analysis of electrical circuits. Power and energy. Two port network theory. Laboratory in basic electrical engineering topics
cousers.Key Words: Numerical Analysis, Power Systems & Energy Engineering, Computer Hardware & Architecture

cousers.Course Name: Programming for Signal and Information Processing Applications
cousers.Course Description: Introduction to programming for signal and information processing. Basic syntax and data types. Packages for data manipulation and visualization. Handling a variety of data formats
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either CSE 122, CSE 123, CSE 142, CSE 143, or CSE 160.
cousers.Key Words: Signal Processing & Communication, Data Science & Data Engineering, Computation & Scientific Computing

cousers.Prerequisites: MATH 135, MATH 207, AMATH 351, E E 241, CSE 163
cousers.Course Description: Introduction to signal processing, including both continuous- and discrete-time signals and systems. Basic signals including impulses, unit steps, periodic signals and complex exponentials. Convolution of signals. Fourier series and transforms. Linear, time-invariant filters. Computer laboratory.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either MATH 135, MATH 207, or AMATH 351, any of which may be taken concurrently; and either E E 241, which may be taken concurrently, or CSE 163.
cousers.Key Words: Signal Processing & Communication, Embedded & Real-Time Systems, Computation & Scientific Computing

cousers.Course Description: Overview of digital computer systems. Covers logic, Boolean algebra, combinational and sequential circuits and logic design; programmable logic devices; and the design and operation of digital computers, including ALU, memory, and I/O. Weekly laboratories.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either CSE 121, CSE 122, CSE 123, CSE 142, or CSE 143.
cousers.Key Words: Computer Hardware & Architecture, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Computer Networks & Security

cousers.Course Description: Overview of modern electronic and photonic devices underlying modern electronic products including smartphones, traffic lights, lasers, solar cells, personal computers, and chargers. Introduction to modeling and principles of physics relevant to the analysis of electrical and optical/photonic devices. recommended: either Python programming or Matlab; and Linux.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: E E 215, which may be taken concurrently; and either PHYS 122 or PHYS 142;
cousers.Key Words: Computer Hardware & Architecture, Quantum Computing & Information, Embedded & Real-Time Systems

cousers.Course Description: New and experimental approaches to basic electrical engineering. May include design and construction projects
cousers.Key Words: Power Systems & Energy Engineering, Bioengineering & Neural Engineering, Software Development & Engineering

cousers.Course Description: Covers the theoretical and mathematical foundations of computation. Logic, set theory, induction, and algebraic structures with applications to computing; models of computation; limits of computability; P, NP, and NP-Complete.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either MATH 126 or MATH 136; and either CSE 123 or CSE 143.
cousers.Key Words: Computation & Scientific Computing, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Quantum Computing & Information

cousers.Course Description: Physics, characteristics, applications, analysis, and design of circuits using semiconductor diodes and field-effect transistors with an emphasis on large-signal behavior and digital logic circuits. Classroom concepts are reinforced through laboratory experiments and design exercises.
cousers.Key Words: Computer Hardware & Architecture, Mathematics Education & Career Development, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Characteristics of bipolar transistors, large- and small- signal models for bipolar and field effect transistors, linear circuit applications, including low and high frequency analysis of differential amplifiers, current sources, gain stages and output stages, internal circuitry of op-amps, op-amp configurations, op-amp stability and compensation. Weekly laboratory.
cousers.Key Words: Computer Hardware & Architecture, Power Systems & Energy Engineering, Signal Processing & Communication

cousers.Course Description: Review of basic signal processing concepts. Two-sided Laplace and z -transforms and connection to Fourier transforms. Modulation, sampling and the fast Fourier transform. Short-time Fourier transform. Multi-rate signal processing. Applications including inference and machine learning. Computer laboratory.
cousers.Key Words: Signal Processing & Communication, Computer-Aided Mathematics, Computation & Scientific Computing

cousers.Course Description: Develops understanding of modern energy systems through theory and analysis of the system and its components. Discussions of generation, transmission, and utilization are complemented by environmental and energy resources topics as well as electromechanical conversion, power electronics, electric safety, renewable energy, and electricity blackouts.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 1.0 in E E 215.
cousers.Key Words: Power Systems & Energy Engineering, Embedded & Real-Time Systems, Signal Processing & Communication

cousers.Course Description: Introductory electromagnetic field theory and Maxwell's equations in integral and differential forms; uniform plane waves in linear media; boundary conditions and reflection and transmission of waves; guided waves; transmission lines and Smith chart; electrostatics.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: a minimum grade of 1.0 in E E 215; and either PHYS 123 or PHYS 143.
cousers.Key Words: Differential Equations & Dynamical Systems, Power Systems & Energy Engineering, Numerical Analysis

cousers.Course Name: Design of Digital Circuits and Systems
cousers.Course Description: Provides a theoretical background in, and practical experience with, tools, and techniques for modeling complex digital systems with the Verilog hardware description language, maintaining signal integrity, managing power consumption, and ensuring robust intra- and inter-system communication.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either E E 205 or E E 215; either E E 271 or CSE 369.
cousers.Key Words: Computer Hardware & Architecture, Embedded & Real-Time Systems, Signal Processing & Communication

cousers.Course Name: Probability for Information and Communication Engineering
cousers.Course Description: Introduces probabilistic concepts for Electrical and Computer Engineering majors with applications to information/data science, signal processing, and communication systems. Includes accompanying Python labs that apply probabilistic concepts to these application domains.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: E E 235 or E E 241; and MATH 126 or MATH 136
cousers.Key Words: Probability & Stochastic Processes, Data Science & Data Engineering, Computer-Aided Mathematics

cousers.Course Description: Practical skills for day-to-day engineering communication as well as an advanced exploration of how to prepare persuasive documents and presentations for technical and non-technical audiences.
cousers.Key Words: Software Development & Engineering, Human-Computer Interaction & UI/UX, Mathematics Education & Career Development

cousers.Course Description: Explores professional issues faced by women as well as sexual and gender minorities (LGBTQ+) in the engineering workplace.
cousers.Key Words: Human-Computer Interaction & UI/UX, Software Development & Engineering, Data Science & Data Engineering

cousers.Course Description: Covers topics of interest to students planning their educational and professional path, including salaries, the value of advanced degrees, societal expectations of engineering professionals, the corporate enterprise, ethical dilemmas, patents and trade secrets, outsourcing, and the global market.
cousers.Key Words: Mathematics Education & Career Development, Software Development & Engineering, Human-Computer Interaction & UI/UX

cousers.Course Description: Explores effective and inclusive teaching techniques in engineering and related STEM fields. Includes active and problem-based learning with attention to how racial, ethnicity, gender, and socioeconomic differences affect how students learn and interact with teachers (including faculty and teaching assistants).
cousers.Key Words: Mathematics Education & Career Development, Human-Computer Interaction & UI/UX, Bioengineering & Neural Engineering

cousers.Course Description: Introduces the role of Innovation and engineering in the design of medical devices and healthcare technologies, applicable both to medical practice and healthcare-focused engineering. May serve as the first course in a medically related senior design project sequence. Discusses medical practice, clinical needs finding, FDA regulation, insurance reimbursement, intellectual property, and the medical device design process.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: Recommended: M E 123 and M E 354.
cousers.Key Words: Software Development & Engineering, Data Science & Data Engineering, Bioengineering & Neural Engineering

cousers.Course Name: Random Signals for Communications and Signal Processing
cousers.Course Description: Probability and random processes in communications. Random variables, distributions, and expectation. Statistical filter design for detection and estimation.
cousers.Detailed Course Prerequisite: either E E 242 or E E 341; either STAT 390, MATH 394/STAT 394, or IND E 315.
cousers.Key Words: Signal Processing & Communication, Probability & Stochastic Processes, Analysis & Real Analysis

cousers.Course Description: Introduction to wireless networks as an application of basic communication theorems. Examines modulation techniques for digital communications, signal space, optimum receiver design, error performance, error control coding for high reliability, mulitpath fading and its effects, RF link budget analysis, WiFi and Wimax systems.
cousers.Key Words: Signal Processing & Communication, Topology & Geometry, Discrete Mathematics & Graph Theory

cousers.Prerequisites: CSE 163, E E 241, MATH 136, MATH 208, MATH 394
